isis.stitle: International® MaxxForce™ 5 Engine Service Manual - Crankcase, Crankshaft, and Camshaft - Cleaning, Inspection and Testing

warning.para: To prevent personal injury or death, wear safety glasses with side shields. Limit compressed air pressure to 207 kPa (30 psi).

note.para: The best way to clean the crankcase during an engine overhaul is in a chemical bath or hot tank. This procedure removes all carbonized material and mineral deposits which collect in coolant passages. When a hot tank is not available, use the following procedure:
Thoroughly clean and inspect crankcase before and after reconditioning.

step1.para: To remove main oil gallery cup plug (16 mm) located in rear of crankcase, use a punch and hammer near the edge of the plug and strike with hammer. Remove plug from crankcase and discard.
Clean main galleries with an Oil Gallery Cleaning Brush .
Spray or wipe main oil gallery cup plug bores with an appropriate cleaning solvent. The bores must be free of any oily residue for the sealant to adhere and be effective.

Coat edges of new oil gallery cup plugs and crankcase joints with Loctite® #620
prior to installing cup plugs.

Use an Oil Gallery Plug Driver to install new oil gallery cup plugs. It should be flush with the crankcase surface to approximately 1.50 mm (0.060 in) below surface. See Special Service Tools
.
Use non-metallic stiff bristle brushes and scrapers to clean gasket material from machined surfaces of crankcase.
Clean cylinder bore with soap, water, and a nylon stiff bristle brush.
Clean lower crankcase in solvent. Dry with filtered compressed air.

Use a Straightedge
to check the crankcase top surface for flatness. Insert a Feeler gauge between the Straightedge and crankcase head surface.

step2.para:
Measure the total deck surface, if any gap exceeds Specifications
, the crankcase must be replaced.

Divide the deck surface into areas of approximately 150 mm 2. Measure each area and if any gap exceeds specifications, the crankcase must be replaced. See Specifications
.

Divide the deck surface into areas of approximately 25 mm 2. Measure each area and if any gap exceeds specifications, the crankcase must be replaced. See Specifications
.

caution.para: Do not resurface the crankcase. Surface defects beyond those listed above cannot be corrected.

To prevent engine damage, threads in the crankcase bolt holes must be clean and blown dry with filtered compressed air. Dirt or oil left in holes may cause binding and a false torque reading during assembly.

step1.para:
Clean all cylinder head bolt holes with Head Bolt Bottoming Tap
. Blow out holes with filtered compressed air.
After cleaning, inspect crankcase for cracks, scoring, roughness or wear at cylinder bores.
If cylinder walls have minor surface damage, but are otherwise within out-of-round specifications, it may be possible to remove such damage by honing.

Use a Cylinder Bore Gauge
to check cylinder bore for out-of-round.

step2.para: Measure diameter of cylinder bore at top of piston ring travel. Be sure to measure at a right angle to the center line of crankshaft (dimension A). Record reading.
Measure each bore so gauge reading coincides with center line of crankshaft (dimension B). Record reading.
The difference between dimension A and dimension B is the out-of-round condition at the top of the cylinder bore.

step1.para: Repeat the same procedure at the bottom of ring travel to check for out-of-round condition.

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, if cylinder bores are deeply scored, out-of-round or exceed specifications, all cylinders must be bored oversize.

step1.para:
If cylinder bore is within specifications, standard size pistons and rings may be used. If cylinder bore is suitable for use without reconditioning, de-glaze the cylinder bore before assembling. See Specifications
.

note.para: If cylinder bores are to be de-glazed, all piston cooling tubes must be removed.

step1.para: Spray both the cylinder to be de-glazed and the de-glazing hone with penetrating fluid or equivalent. This spray contains colloidal graphite and works well for this application.

step2.para:
Attach a De-glazing hone
to a variable speed electric or air powered drill.

note.para: A speed of approximately 100 to 120 rpm is required. Speed adjustment is required for the procedure to be successful.

step2.para: De-glaze cylinder wall for about 15 seconds. Stroke bore up and down at a rate of one complete up and down stroke per second.
Withdraw de-glazing hone from cylinder bore while brush is rotating. Wipe portion of cylinder wall and inspect cross hatch pattern.

note.para: The cross hatch pattern left by the abrasive tool should be approximately 45°.

step2.para: If pattern is "flatter" than required, increase up and down stroke speed or slow down drill rotation as required.
Continue de-glazing cylinder bore for 10 to 15 seconds or 20 to 25 strokes.
Wipe cylinder bore clean and inspect bore for proper 45° cross hatch pattern.

step1.para: After de-glazing, thoroughly clean cylinder bores with soft bristle brush, soap and water. Dry with filtered compressed air. Lubricate bore with clean engine oil.
